WATER_NAME: Cherry Creek - ephemeral tributaries
Lake Fork - source to Sublett Reservoir
COMMENT: Raft River TMDL Approoved 2004 listed for bacteria page 87   Bacteria counts were very low throughout the early part of the year. However, samples collected  after July were typically higher. Instantaneous criteria were exceeded once in August. However,  follow-up monitoring was not completed to determine if a water quality violation had occurred.  The instantaneous violation appears to have been an isolated event. Samples collected within the  same month were low and the following month samples were even lower (the proceeding  month???s data are not available). However, due to the potential for bacteria contamination, as  seen in other systems within the subbasin, DEQ will continue to monitor bacteria concentrations  throughout the TMDL development phase. At this time, DEQ feels that a TMDL for nutrients  may alleviate the need for concern, as the implementation strategies would be similar for both  nutrients and bacteria given that rangeland activities are the most prevalent land use. Additional  monitoring throughout the TMDL development stage and implementation phase will address the  needs concerning bacteria in Lake Fork Creek.pg 91see page 92 for graph. swoodhead 1/15/10     2/02/2012 (Sean Woodhead) - 17040210SK022_02 was monitored in 2011 to reassess Secondary Contact Recreation. Fall Creek, Lake Fork Creek, and Van Camp Creek are contained within this AU. The geometric mean from 5 e.coli samples on Fall Creek was 2813 cfu/100 ml. The geometric mean from Lake Fork Creek was 286 cfu/100ml. Van Camp Creek was not sample due to lack of flow.

WATER_NAME: Rainey Creek - source to mouth
COMMENT: 6/8/2015 (MH) - Samples for E. coli taken in 1999 show exceedance of geometric mean criteria during base-flow conditions for contact recreation. The calculated geometric mean was 200 cfu/100 mL (Table 6 of the  Palisades TMDL). Due to protocol error, only four samples were taken in 2010 showing water quality standards being met (Figure 5). Five samples are needed to calculate the geometric mean for compliance with state water quality standards. Due to this error, an E. coli TMDL was written for the Rainey Creek AU using the 1999 data.    7/10/17 (JW, TS): A single E. coli sample collected 8/21/13 had a concentration of 77.1 cfu/100 mL.

COMMENT: 12/3/2013 (NED) - The Portneuf River TMDL Revision and Addendum approved July 29, 2010 established a reservoir target for dissolved oxygen of 6.0 mg/L and a chlorophyll a target of 0.015 mg/L. However, EPA claims in their comments to the draft 2012 IR that DEQ did not provide an explanation as to why the chlorophyll a target was selected; no explanation of why this is an appropriate surrogate for DO impairment, no loading capacity, load allocations, margin of safety and discussion on seasonable variation for chlorophyll a. Therefore, DEQ moved DO back to Category 5 and has no intention on developing another TMDL to address DO.

Sublett Creek - source to Sublett Reservoir
COMMENT: The overarching water quality problem in Sublett Creek is not any of the previously mentioned  water quality parameters. It is simply flow alteration. Typically, any water quality guideline or  standard, if it is violated, is violated when the water is shut off to the creek. Temperature, low  DO, and TSS are usually the parameters associated with flow alteration problems. In Sublett  Creek???s case, these parameters are buffered by the upstream watersheds water source and  quality. However, the beneficial uses of the creek remain impaired due to long periods of zero  flow during the spring filling period and during the summer when water is not required for the  crops.   See Raft River TMDL approver 2004 page 222 s.woodhead 1/10/10    BURP DAta supports assessment calls for smi as fully supportijng. 2006STWFA031 Sublett Creek  sw1/18/10

COMMENT: 4/17/2012 (JT) - This assessment unit was assessed in 2006 by the Beneficial Use Reconnaissance Program (BURP) crew and received an SFI score of 91.6 in 2006, indicating a passing fisheries index score. Young of the year salmonids were again observed by the BURP field crew in 2011 indicating that salmonid spawning is occurring. A TMDL has been developed for this assessment unit for temperature and total phosphorus. Because the temperature criteria for salmonid spawning is more strict than the temperature criteria for cold water aquatic life and cold water aquatic life is not supporting, therefore salmonid spawning is not supporting.

Trapper Creek - source to Squaw Creek
COMMENT: 1/4/2010 (S.Woodhead) - he test indicated that the percent surface fines between the fully supported segment and lower Trapper Creek were significantly different (p <0.02). As a result of the differences between the percent fines of the two streams, DEQ has determined that bedload sediment as measured by the percent surface fines surrogate is impairing the lower segment of Trapper Creek. Samples collected in other fully supported streams indicate that percent fines within the wetted width should be 25 percent or less (Lay 2000). Thus it appears that bedload is impairing the beneficial uses of the lower segment of Trapper Creek. page 72    2006STWFA004 Trapper Creek   2006STWFA002 Fall Creek   2006STWFA003 Trapper Creek   all sites meet CWAL  2008STWFA038 Fall Creek   2008STWFA063 Trapper Creek   See page 69 of the Goose Creek TMDL approved 2004 discussing TP  http://www.deq.idaho.gov/water/data_reports/surface_water/tmdls/goose_creek/goose_creek_chap2.pdf

COMMENT: In the DEQ data set Goose Creek, Trapper Creek, Birch Creek, Little Cottonwood Creek, Beaverdam Creek, and Left Hand Fork Beaverdam Creek exceeded the daily maximum TSS guideline (80 mg/L). WATER_NAME: Schweitzer Creek - headwaters to Sand Cr.
COMMENT: 2010: Schweitzer Creek AU was assessed on 1/6/2010 by CDA RO Staff (R. Steed, K. Stromberg, K. Keith, T. Clyne, J. Bergquist). Schweitzer Creek is included in the 2007 Pend Oreille Sediment TMDLs for sediment (LA table 5-4 page 78, table 5-9 page 81).  2006 BURP score (2006SCDAA051) indicate AU may qualify for the full support category. We are unaware of restoration activities or other watershed improvements that may account for the change in score. In fact numerous complaint responses in the upper portion of the watershed indicate that sediment loading is increasing.  We have documented poor or no erosion and sediment control practices for example: excavation of a stream channel, landslides, fine sediment filled stream channels, poor storm water management, traction sand management issues.  The WAG requested that IDEQ take a special look at Schweitzer Creek for excess sediment.  A Sand Creek Stressor Identification report has been developed as part of the SBA process that clearly identifies sediment as a problem for Schweitzer Creek.  Given this information and TMDL status, we recommend that Schweitzer Creek remain in category 4a for sediment.

WATER_NAME: North Fork Grouse Creek - headwaters to Grouse Cr
COMMENT: 2010: North Fork Grouse Creek AU was assessed on 1/6/2010 by CDA RO Staff (R.Steed, T. Clyne). North Fork Grouse Creek is included in the 2001 Clark Fork/Pend Oreille TMDLs for sediment (p72-77, LA p 86) as part of the Pack River Watershed. Grouse Creek is also included in the 2007 Pend Oreille Tributaries Temperature TMDLs (p 25). 2006 BURP scores indicate AU may qualify for the full support category. We are unaware of restoration activities or other watershed improvements that may account for the change in score. Given this lack of information and TMDL status, we recommend further investigation and inclusion of Grouse Creek in category 4a for sediment and temperature. The Temperature TMDL was approved by EPA in 2008. Temperature impairment for this stream was moved to category 4a on this date which is a delisting from category 5.

Trapper Creek - source to Squaw Creek
COMMENT: 1/4/2010 (S. Woodhead) - 2008STWFA063 Trapper Creek  70.80 3 Basins 91.28 3 Rangeland 58.00 2 No.Basins 2.67 2008STWFA038 Fall Creek  55.04 3 Basins 91.03 3 Rangeland 54.00 2 No.Basins 2.67. Both sites show full support for cwal and ss. The test indicated that the percent surface fines between the fully supported segment and lower Trapper Creek were significantly different (p <0.02). As a result of the differences between the percent fines of the two streams, DEQ has determined that bedload sediment as measured by the percent surface fines surrogate is impairing the lower segment of Trapper Creek. Samples collected in other fully supported streams indicate that percent fines within the wetted width should be 25 percent or less (Lay 2000). Thus it appears that bedload is impairing the beneficial uses of the lower segment of Trapper Creek. page 72. See The Goose Creek TMDL approved in 2004. http://www.deq.idaho.gov/water/data_reports/surface_water/tmdls/goose_creek/goose_creek_entire.pdf     4/23/2012 (S. Woodhead) - Changed salmonid spawning to an existing use. Fish data from BURP sites 2008STWFA063, 2008STWFA038, 2003STWFA057, 1997STWFA040 and 1996STWFB014 demonstrate evidence of salmonids less than 100mm (Idaho's WBAG II, p. 3-9).

COMMENT: 7/12/2021 (RE): This is a newly-created assessment unit for the 2022 Integrated Report and was split from AU ID17010214PN041_02 - Upper Pack River - tributaries above Hellroaring Cr. This AU will remain in Category 4a for Total Phosphorus, Sedimentation/Siltation, and Temperature.

WATER_NAME: Jeru Creek - source to mouth
COMMENT: 2010: This assessment unit has a TMDL for temperature, 2007 Pend Oreille Tributaries Temperature TMDLs, approved by EPA in April 2008. CDA RO Staff reviewed this water body 1/12/2010 to update assessment status due to TMDL. The "cause" temperature was moved from Category 5 to 4a.  12/17/2019 Assessment by K. Larson DEQ-CRO: 2014 and 2017 BURP scores indicate the cold water aquatic life beneficial use in Jeru Creek is no longer impaired by sediment.  In both years, BURP scores indicate the stream had low percent fines (substrate was large cobbles and boulders), low embeddedness, and banks were 100% stable and covered.  However, this AU is part of a watershed sediment load reduction requirement for the Pack River watershed in the 2001 Clark Fork/Pend Oreille Subbasin Assessment and TMDL. Because sediment load reductions necessary to meet beneficial use support have not been met in the watershed, this AU will remain under the constraints of the 2001 Clark Fork/Pend Oreille Subbasin Assessment and TMDL.

COMMENT: This assessment unit was evaluated by IDEQ and sediment was identified as the pollutant driving the impairment.  Idaho Falls Regional office staff drafted a sediment TMDL which was approved by EPA Region X in March, 2003.  The data gathered through the Beneficial Use Reconnaissance Program and represented in by BURP ID 2001SIDFA050 confirm the impairment and indicate beneficial uses have not been restored.  The Idaho Soil Conservation Commission is charged with drafting the TMDL implementation plan for the private lands impacted.  The TMDL may be downloaded from the IDEQ web page at: http://www.deq.state.id.us/water/tmdls/tmdls.htm#IdahoFalls\

WATER_NAME: Weiser River - Little Weiser River to Keithly Creek
COMMENT: From the Weiser River TMDL, page xxvii:  A biological assessment was completed on the middle Weiser River per Idaho Water  Body Assessment Guidance (Grafe et al. 2002), and the results of this assessment  indicated the following:  ??? The River Fish Index score was ???below minimal threshold,??? indicating the segment is  not supporting the cold water aquatic life designated use or salmonid spawning.  ??? Bacteria monitoring conducted in 2001 and 2002 showed Idaho water quality  geometric mean criteria were not exceeded, indicating primary contact recreation is  fully supported.  ??? Water temperatures showed exceedances of Idaho water quality criteria for maximum  daily average temperature and daily average temperature; this is a major influence on  downstream water temperatures.  The biological assessment also indicated a high presence of sediment tolerant species.  Analysis of macroinvertebrate and periphyton species indicated that sediment is  impairing the composition and diversity of the indicator species present in the middle  Weiser River. Consequently, a total maximum daily load for total suspended solids and a  substrate target have been established to protect designated beneficial uses:  ??? A total suspended solid target of 50 mg/L monthly average will need to be met to  protect the designated beneficial uses. A load reduction for total suspended solids will  require an overall reduction of 11-45% during high loading periods.  ??? A substrate target of no more than 30% of the substrate as fine sediment (<6 mm) has  also been established.    1/8/10  HS

WATER_NAME: Trapper Creek
COMMENT: In the DEQ data set Goose Creek, Trapper Creek, Birch Creek, Little Cottonwood Creek, Beaverdam Creek, and Left Hand Fork Beaverdam Creek exceeded the daily maximum TSS guideline (80 mg/L). These exceedances typically occurred in spring sampling events. However, the exceedances in both Beaverdam Creeks were late summer events. Monthly average exceedances (TSS guideline of 50 mg/L) were less frequent. Goose Creek had elevated sediment in April and May 2002; Trapper Creek had elevated sediment in May 2001and April, May, and June 2002 on the creek. See  Goose Creek Subbasin Assessment and TMDL pgs. 47 and 48, approved 2004.

WATER_NAME: Pickett Creek - 3rd order
TMDL_NAME: Mid Snake River/Succor Creek Tributaries Sediment TMDL 2013 Addendum
COMMENT: In 2010 and 2011, the Boise Regional Office devised a simple bank-stability method that could be used to determine whether this assessment unit was impaired by sediment.  Field work was conducted in the spring of 2010 and fall of 2011.  Approximately five miles (one-third) of the length of this channel was surveyed.    The episodic nature of sediment pollution in intermittent streams makes direct monitoring extremely difficult.  To solve this problem, a bank stability approach was used.  Banks were considered stable if they did not show indications of breakdown, slump, fracture, or vertical erosion.    DEQ typically considers 80% stability to be the threshold for sediment impairment.  The banks of this assessment unit were found to be 82% stable, but the erosion was severe and warranted further investigation.  Further monitoring should occur, and if necessary, a TMDL should be developed.    Final results are available in the documents 'Intermittent Streams Monitoring in the Boise Region: Spring 2010. Results and Field Summary', DEQ, December 2010, and 'Intermittent Streams Monitoring in the Boise Region: Fall 2011.  Results and Field Summary', DEQ, December 2011.  TRIM refs. 2010AKL104 and 2012AKL7 respectively.    HS 3/7/12

WATER_NAME: Blue Creek Reservoir
COMMENT: From Upper Owyhee TMDL (approved March 2003), page xxvii    Blue Creek Reservoir is a small in-stream impoundment located on Blue Creek in the Blue Creek  Reservoir 5th Field HUC. The reservoir is approximately 185 acres in size and has a storage  capacity of 250 acre/feet. The primary water use is irrigation water storage. In 2000, the Idaho  Department of Fish and Game introduced domestic Kamloops trout in the reservoir. With the  stocking of the Kamloops, the reservoir has been determined to have cold water aquatic life as an  existing use and criteria to support this existing use therefore applies.

COMMENT: From the Weiser River TMDL, page xxvii:  A biological assessment was completed on the middle Weiser River per Idaho Water  Body Assessment Guidance (Grafe et al. 2002), and the results of this assessment  indicated the following:  ??? The River Fish Index score was ???below minimal threshold,??? indicating the segment is  not supporting the cold water aquatic life designated use or salmonid spawning.  ??? Bacteria monitoring conducted in 2001 and 2002 showed Idaho water quality  geometric mean criteria were not exceeded, indicating primary contact recreation is  fully supported.  ??? Water temperatures showed exceedances of Idaho water quality criteria for maximum  daily average temperature and daily average temperature; this is a major influence on  downstream water temperatures.  The biological assessment also indicated a high presence of sediment tolerant species.  Analysis of macroinvertebrate and periphyton species indicated that sediment is  impairing the composition and diversity of the indicator species present in the middle  Weiser River. Consequently, a total maximum daily load for total suspended solids and a  substrate target have been established to protect designated beneficial uses:  ??? A total suspended solid target of 50 mg/L monthly average will need to be met to  protect the designated beneficial uses. A load reduction for total suspended solids will  require an overall reduction of 11-45% during high loading periods.  ??? A substrate target of no more than 30% of the substrate as fine sediment (<6 mm) has  also been established.    1/8/10  HS

Salmonid Spawning (SS) is Not Supporting due to the exceedance of SS daily maximum criteria (13 degrees C) and daily average temperature criteria (9 degrees C) more than 10% of the time.

SF Salmon River and tribs above EFSF - 1st and 2nd order
TMDL_NAME: SF SALMON RIVER TEMPERATURE TMDLS (& REVISED SEDIMENT TARGETS)
COMMENT: December 2009 (HS) - Site re-assessed as Fully Supporting CWAL.  Excellent fish assemblages at the regular-season BURP sites.    Seven BURP sites were placed on this (very large) assessment unit in 2007.  However, rhree of the sites were part of a Forest-Service pilot project, and were monitored 1) out of the BURP index season and 2) in heavily, and freshly, fire-damaged areas.  They should not be considered as part of the average score.    The four regular-season sites were extremely good, and show full support of CWAL:  Nasty Creek 3  Two-Bit Creek 3  Indian Creek 3  Mormon Creek 2.67    The three post-season sites failed, in each case, mainly due to poor fish index scores.  This is to be expected after a very intense forest fire:  Bear Creek 3  Lodgepole Creek 1.67  Lodgepole Creek 0

This assessment unit was evaluated by IDEQ and sediment and temperature were identified as the pollutant driving the impairment. The Idaho Soil Conservation Commission is charged with drafting the TMDL implementation plan for the private lands impacted. WATER_NAME: Rose Creek
TMDL_NAME: COEUR D'ALENE LAKE TRIBUTARIES TEMPERATURE TMDL
COMMENT: This AU was assessed on 1/19/2010 by CDA RO Staff (R. Steed, K. Keith, T. Clyne, and K. Stromberg). Temperature data were submitted by U.S. Forest Service, Idaho Panhandle National Forests, Coeur d'Alene River Ranger District as response to DEQ request for data. These data were assessed as Tier 1 by K. Stromberg and K. Duncan (DEQ intern) in 2009. The analysis can be found in a report attached and data are available at CDA Regional Office and on the Regional Office Shared Drive G:WATRQUAL\INTEGRATED REPORT\Data and Documentation for 2010. Salmonid spawning as existing beneficial use was confirmed by USFS staff. Temperature data in this AU exceeded Idaho water quality standards for salmonid spawning criteria. Based on WBAGII, we concluded this AU not fully supporting for CWAL and SS.

WATER_NAME: Upper Johnson Creek and tributaries - 1st and 2nd order
TMDL_NAME: SF SALMON RIVER TEMPERATURE TMDLS (& REVISED SEDIMENT TARGETS)
COMMENT: (HS) - This assessment was based upon eleven BURP sites, mostly sampled in 2008.  This is a very large assessment unit, and is comprised of many small first and second order streams.  Eleven sites is more than adequate to characterize the assessment unit.  The high number is partly because of the presence of a reference/trend site that is visited every year. Every site scored 3 out of 3 for the macroinvertebrate index, except one site that scored 2.  This indicates that Cold Water Aquatic Life is fully supported. However, two of the sites had a poor fish assemblage, and Boise National Forest temperature data indicate that the Bull Trout temperature standard is violated. For that reason, this water body is determined to fully support CWAL, and not fully support SS.

WATER_NAME: Nickel Creek & tributaries - 1st and 2nd order
Payette Lake - Eastside tribs, inc.Lemah & parts of Fall Cr.
TMDL_NAME: NORTH FORK PAYETTE RIVER SUBBASIN TMDL
COMMENT: From 2005 TMDL, page 120: Fall Creek is listed for temperature on the 1998 303(d) list. Recovery has occurred in this watershed and beneficial uses are not impaired with the exception of cold water aquatic life uses during salmonid spawning season. Instream temperatures during the salmonid spawning season do not meet the temperature criterion. Stream protection protocols are in place and the exceedances of the salmonid spawning criteria appear largely attributable to the results of the Blackwell Fire. Recovery continues to occur and should continue to contribute to lower temperatures. Using aerial photos, pre and post burn vegetative cover were compared. A shading target of 85% was developed using shade curves for similar Douglas Fir-Grand Fir vegetative community types by averaging results for streams of a similar width and aspect from these TMDLs: the Walla Walla (ODEQ 2004b), Willamette (ODEQ 2004a), Mattole (CRWQCB 2002) and South Fork Clearwater (IDEQ 2002) TMDLs. A TMDL was determined for Fall Creek for salmonid spawning temperatures.

Young of the year salmonids were again observed by the BURP field crew in 2011 indicating that salmonid spawning is occurring. A TMDL has been developed for this assessment unit for temperature and total phosphorus. Because the temperature criteria for salmonid spawning is more strict than the temperature criteria for cold water aquatic life and cold water aquatic life is not supporting, therefore salmonid spawning is not supporting.

WATER_NAME: Johnson Creek - 4th order
TMDL_NAME: SF SALMON RIVER TEMPERATURE TMDLS (& REVISED SEDIMENT TARGETS)
COMMENT: From 2002 SBA, page 52:    These results indicate that increases in stream temperatures to the evaluated water bodies are  either at or less than 1 oC during the time of criteria exceedances. These low increases in  stream temperature fall within the possible error associated with estimated and measured  parameters used in the SSTemp model (i.e. base flow, shade quality and quantity, etc.).  Therefore, the stream temperatures obtained for these water bodies are considered to be  reflective of natural conditions, and the Idaho water quality standards for streams with bull  trout are not violated. However, the federal temperature standard for bull trout is exceeded.  Therefore, the IDEQ places (Johnson Creek) on the 303(d) list  for the State of Idaho based on federal bull trout stream temperature standard violations (i.e.  no Idaho water quality standards are currently violated).  04/16/2021 (EW): USFS data collected from 2016-2017, and from 2019-2020 on Johnson Creek indicate that the EPA 1997 Bull Trout temperature criteria (10 degrees maximum weekly maximum temperature) is exceeded in 2016, 2019, and 2020. This means that Cold Water Aquatic Life (CWAL) and Salmonid Spawning (SS) are both Not Supporting.

Spring Creek - source to North Leigh Creek, including spring
Willow Creek - Crane Creek to Mud Creek
COMMENT: This assessment unit was evaluated by IDEQ and sediment, temperature, and nutrients were identified as the pollutants driving the impairment.  Idaho Falls Regional office staff drafted temperature, sediment, and nutrient TMDLs which were approved by EPA Region X in July, 2004.  The data gathered through the Beneficial Use Reconnaissance Program and represented in by BURP ID 2001SIDFA100.  The assessment indicated full support for CWAL, SS uses.  This AU will remain in the section of the Integrated Report that catalogs approved TMDLs.      Because 2003 BURP showed ALUS = fully supporting, but numeric criteria are not available, the assumption is made, as per WBAG II, Section 6.5, that salmonid spawning is fully supporting. No fish data is available at the time of assessment. The stream is listed for sediment/siltation.

COMMENT: 3/3/17 (C. Nelson): Salmonid spawning remains not supporting due to numeric criteria exceedances for temperature, 1997SCDATL0032.Salmonid spawning is an existing use, defined by WBAG III, 3.2.2 evaluating BURP data from 2015SCDAA034. WATER_NAME: Big Creek - source to mouth
TMDL_NAME: ST. JOE RIVER SUBBASIN TEMPERATURE TMDL ADDENDUM
COMMENT: 2012 (R. Steed) - The newest BURP data suggests full support of beneficial uses.  The low percent fines measured during the two newest BURP surveys, the passing BURP scores, and the low embeddedness scores suggests that fine sediment is not negatively impacting aquatic life beneficial uses.  A temperature TMDL has been developed to address the water temperature exceedance.  The macroinvertebrate bioassessment listing should be removed from Category 5 of the Integrated Report, and the assessment unit should be moved to Category 4a because of the completed and approved temperature TMDL. Refer to the St. Joe Subbasin 2010 Integrated Report Macroinvertebrate Bioassessment Listing document for details.
